BE

This morning GSK announced that Emma Walmsley (EW), who currently runs GSK Consumer, will succeed Andrew Witty as CEO from 31st March 2017. Emma was believed to be one of two internal candidates, based on previous press speculation (our previous alert here, the other being Abbas Hussein, President Global Pharmaceuticals), however there had subsequently been comments attributed to GSK Chairman Philip Hampton at the AGM in May that the board was only considering candidates with Healthcare experience (“The only candidates we would consider are people who are very seriously in the health-care sector”), which had been interpreted by the market to mean a candidate with a Pharma, rather than Consumer background. There had also been comments attributed to Hampton that GSK would look to raise the pay scale for their CEO to be more globally competitive (“it will be relatively expensive”), which was interpreted by the market to mean a potential US hire. We believe the market may be surprised that the board has chosen a CEO with a Consumer, rather than a Pharma background, though on the positive side, we believe EW is well liked by investors who have had the chance to meet her.

PM

It's a menace

BE

EW has 5 years of experience running Consumer at GSK, and lengthy experience in Consumer prior to GSK at L’Oreal. EW has extensive experience at GSK, having joined in 2010, and having run the Consumer division since 2011. Prior to this, she was at L’Oreal for 17 years, holding a variety of marketing and management roles in the UK, Europe and the US, as well as being GM of Consumer Products in China. EW is also a non-executive director of Diageo. She holds an MA in Classics and Modern languages. EW hasn’t featured in quarterly calls, but did present at last year’s Capital Market’s day, so investors will already be familiar with her. We believe EW has already met with many investors in the context of her current role, particularly in the UK, and we have received positive feedback from those who have interacted with her.

11:12 am
BE

I know. I mean, it's a document reader, reading a format that's nearly two decades old. That's all it needs to do. And it doesn't.

BE

EWs appointment may be read as ruling out divestment / spinning-off the Consumer division, suggesting the group will maintain the current diversified structure, also implies GSK are likely to buy out the Novartis minority. Some investors have previously expressed the view that GSK could realise value by spinning off the Consumer division, unwinding a conglomerate discount, with GSK instead focusing on Pharma and Vaccines. We believe the choice of a candidate with a Consumer background to run the entire company makes this seem unlikely, as EW would be an odd choice to run a new look GSK without a Consumer division, and it would also seem odd for her to depart with any potential Consumer spin-off, requiring another CEO appointment for GSK in a short space of time. We believe this morning’s news will also be read that Consumer will become a bigger focus at GSK, and hence GSK will likely attempt to buy out Novartis’ 36.5% interest in the Consumer JV, which is at Novartis’ discretion, with Novartis having a Put which they can exercise from March 2018. With EW as CEO, we expect an increased focus on Consumer, and a greater emphasis on building a sustainably growing company, with less focus on pipelines and pharma. We could also see more capital allocation toward the Consumer division. An argument could be made that this could help drive a further GSK multiple re-rating, upward in the direction of Consumer companies, with staples now trading at a c.40% PEG premium to Pharma in Europe.

BE

We believe EWs key challenge will be to expand the Pharma pipeline and accelerate Pharma growth. Significant progress has been made at GSK’s Consumer division, with the Novartis integration well underway, margins exceeding initial expectations, and solid topline growth anticipated. The key challenges facing GSK are: (1) the relatively small late stage pipeline, which could be expanded by accelerating development of internally developed assets, or via in-licensing, (2) navigating the US generic Advair expiry which is likely to begin next March, with the challenge being to drive continued growth of the newer respiratory assets through this pressure. More generally, the new CEO will be running a company that still has a very high dividend payout (still c.100% of FCF next year), fairly high leverage (2.3x net Debt / EBITDA next year), and a number of potential demands on cash, including the Novartis Consumer Put option, and Pfizer and Shionogi Put options on their 22% ownership of the HIV business.

BE

During Emma Walmsley's tenure as head of OTC, GSK's OTC business increased from
£ 5.0bn in 2010 to £ 7.1bn in 2016, i.e. an increase of 42% in six years. She successfully
oversaw the asset swap with Novartis in this division at the beginning of 2015. Recent quarters reflect a rapid recovery in operating margins: 14.1% in Q2 2016 vs 7.2% in Q2 2015, already close to the medium-term target of 18%. Her appointment as group CEO suggests that GSK could be tempted to buy out the minority shareholders of the consumer health business (36.5% stake owned by Novartis), which would have an accretive impact on EPS and would bolster the company's growth profile, already amongst the strongest in the sector (2015-2020e CAGR of 11.7% vs 9.0% for the sector). Buy recommendation maintained.

The scale of disruption that Brexit could cause in the City of London has been revealed by figures showing that 5,500 UK-registered firms rely on “passports” to do business in other European countries.

More than 8,000 financial services firms based in the EU or the European Economic Area rely on single market passports to do business in the UK, according to numbers from the Financial Conduct Authority released on Tuesday, reports Martin Arnold, Banking Editor.

11:27 am
BE

China’s strong FAI has been the major demand surprise this year. With
the exception of coal, commodity supply has generally played out as expected
this year but demand has certainly exceeded expectations. While the Chinese
authorities focussed on reform and anti-corruption in 2015, in 2016 the policy
priorities have shifted to ensuring growth does not fall below the 6.5% target,
and authorities have chosen to, once again, lean on fixed asset investment to
achieve their objectives. We expect no change in strategy before the Politburo
seats are finalised in mid-2017. This likely means a renewed liquidity push in
early 2017, which will be supportive of metals demand for the next 12 months.

BE

Coking and thermal coal see the largest uplift. The exceptional strength in
coking and thermal coal prices is squarely down to China’s “276-day” supply
reform initiative which has seen domestic production fall by 10-20% YoY since
late-March. As a result, we have significantly increased our thermal and
coking coal price forecasts (24-35% in 2017) and this has contributed
meaningfully to our earnings upgrades for the miners with coal exposure.

BE

Copper pared back but zinc and aluminium nudged higher: We have cut
our copper price forecast by 5-7% in 2017-18 due to our expectation of a
sustained market surplus. In zinc, tightening fundamentals and poor visibility
on Glencore mine restarts have contributed to an uplift of 4% in 2017-18,
while our aluminium forecast has increased by 6% in 2017 on price strength.

11:27 am
BE

Upgrade to Outperform – BHP Billiton & South32. Our coal/manganese
price upgrades have contributed meaningfully to the 11% and 75% uplift in
CY17E EBITDA forecasts for BHP and S32, respectively. This has led us to
raise our TP by 18% to £12.60 for BHP and by more than two-thirds for S32 to
£1.50. BHP has been upgraded from Neutral to Outperform while S32 has
seen a double upgrade to Outperform.

BE

(@Vixal: here's my bio. See if that helps answer your question: http://ftalphavill...-team/bryce-elder/ )

BE

Upgrade to Neutral – Anglo American & Nyrstar. We’ve increased our
EBITDA forecasts for Anglo by 10-18% on CY17-18 on higher coal/
manganese price forecasts and increased our TP to £8.15. This, coupled with
our view that Anglo’s year end net debt target should be comfortably
achieved, has led us to upgrade the stock to Neutral. The 26% fall in
Nyrstar’s share price and the modest uplift to our zinc forecasts are enough
for us to upgrade the stock to Neutral.

11:28 am
BE

 Key picks: We favour Rio, BHP and S32 amongst the majors due to the
potential for consensus earnings upgrades and favourable valuation metrics.
KAZ remains our top pick amongst the base metals as it continues its striking
transformation. Amongst the small caps, Anglo Pacific offers unrivalled
coking coal exposure while Gemfields remains deeply undervalued.
 Key shorts: ArcelorMittal remains a highly operationally levered producer,
and its margins will suffer from Q1/17 if iron ore and coal prices are sustained
at the current high levels. Antofagasta remains expensively priced with 2016
production risk.

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,385, up 26.01 (+1.10%), High: 2,398, Low: 2,354, Volume: 1.09m
Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 865.95, up 5.05 (+0.59%), High: 873.70, Low: 858.50, Volume: 1.34m
11:29 am
BE

Christopher LaFemina at Jefferies is also talking Chinese coal, and also pushing BHP.

BE

Work day restrictions have led to coking coal shortages: The Chinese government
plans on closing almost 40% of the country's 11,000 coal mines by 2019, with up to 750
million tonnes of coal capacity to be closed over that period. In April, China announced a
reduction in allowable working days for coal miners from 330 to 276 per year. The resulting
increase in coal prices (thermal coal prices in China are up greater than 50% this year) has greatly benefited the domestic coal miners and protected the banks exposed to the industry. The unintended consequence of these closures is that coking coal shortages in China have emerged, and seaborne coking coal prices have more than doubled over the past six weeks.
The Chinese government is concerned about price volatility and is allowing some domestic
miners to increase output of thermal coal. Coking coal capacity in China (and elsewhere)
is likely to ramp up as well since domestic prices continue to increase. While the price
should begin to fall imminently as supply increases, the outlook has clearly improved due
to regulations in Chinese coal mining and underinvestment in coal mine capacity all around
the world.
Changing our coking coal price forecasts: While we expect demand for coking coal
to be weak as Chinese steel production falls over the next two years, the risk to our demand
forecasts is increasingly to the upside as Chinese demand indicators are improving. Even
if demand is weak, supply constraints in the global coal industry should lead to relatively
tight markets. We have increased our fourth quarter coking coal contract price forecast
from $100/t to $170/t (the current bid/ask during negotiations is $160/$180). We have also
increased our coking coal price forecasts from $90/t for all four quarters in 2017 to $140/t
in 1Q, $120/t in 2Q, and $110/t in 3Q and 4Q. We expect the market to be relatively tight
in 2017 as Chinese mine capacity closures are likely to be enforced more strictly as prices
fall, thereby limiting the decline. We also expect operating issues to significantly increase in
the global coal industry as mines have been undercapitalized and maintenance spending
in some cases has been deferred.

BE

BE

At Q1 Kantar under-reported Tesco's growth by 120bps, Sainsbury's growth by 160bps and Morrisons' growth by 80bps. Morrisons' sales at Q2 beat Kantar by 110bps (Kantar implied -1.8% total sales growth compared to Morrisons' actual of -0.7%).

BE

Why? Dunno. The upshot today is that even without that, it's another decent read for Tesco.

11:39 am
BE

Jefferies can summarise.

BE

Industry growth has remained largely subdued in recent weeks in the UK, despite the strong weather conditions. Discounters' outperformance has continued at a more subdued level than in H1, and the majors' lag is slightly more contained. Morrisons remains at the head of the pack on LFL progress, while ASDA is still in retreat. Tesco's progress appears solid, and likely at least partly achieved at a cost to Sainsbury's food performance.

BE

Supportive weather conditions failed to translate into strong demand, with total till roll growth of +0.6% (previous YTD +0.4%). Big four performance of -1.5% compares to -1.9% YTD, confirming a slight reduction in the group's industry underperformance. German discounters' growth remains buoyant at 10.3%, but this is still a more modest industry outperformance so far in H2 (at slightly above 10%, after c.14% in H1). Waitrose seems to have regained significant trading momentum (at 8.5% in this period, after 1.4% YTD), which appears to have capped M&S' progress to 4.1% (vs 5.5% YTD). Food sales at the big four continue to be impacted by strong levels of deflation and contracted by 2.2% in this period (vs -2.9% YTD), with non-food still amply positive at +1.9%.

11:39 am
BE

Tesco progress continues... with cash sales growth of +0.5% suggesting similar levels of LFL gains, lining up a solid interims update (due on 5 October).

...seemingly capping Sainsbury's performance. JS' cash sales of -1.1% suggest a LFL decline of c.2% over the period. Non-food performance remains strong (at +6.4%), flattering what appears to be mounting pressures in the core food business.

Morrisons LFL sales remain best in class, as cash sales of -2.4% (on a space decline of 2.9%) suggests LFL increases of around 1% to 1.5%. Indeed, we believe that the non-repetition of last year's Summer Bonus Campaign would have depressed the Kantar reading, masking the true progress of the business on an underlying basis.

Things remain tough at ASDA, and while a cash sales fall of -4.5% confirms an improvement on the previous YTD of -5.1%, it was achieved against a much softer comparable base. LFL declines at Wal-Mart's subsidiary appear to be close to -6%.

BE

In the paper overnight we flagged up some optimism ahead of Tesco's H1s on October 5.

BE

The idea being that the "farm brands" nonsense has been going for six months now, so management might be able to give some idea about how much price they're giving up for volume.

11:51 am
PM

Q: Is the sector well positioned to absorb a deflationary scenario?
Yes. We believe strong balance sheets, a rational land market, limited apartment build and policy
support (via Help-to-Buy) leave the sector well positioned to absorb a market downturn.
Q: Is a flat market scenario reasonable?
We believe so. While the economic uncertainties are clearly high, we believe good affordability levels,
a healthy mortgage market and a likely absence of financial distress across the sector means 0%
house price deflation and 0% volume drop is a reasonable new base case at this stage.
Q: Can dividends be maintained?
Yes. We see dividend cover at 1.9x 2017E on our forecasts and 1.3x on a FCF basis, which means the
7% yield looks relatively safe, absent a more extreme house price deflation scenario.

PM

The market is still pricing in modest house price deflation
Our new base case of 0% pricing growth suggests 20% average upside potential (25% TSR), which
means the market is still pricing in modest house price deflation. In a scenario where house prices fall
by 5% and volumes drop by 10% vs our base case, our FVs would suggest 25% average downside
potential.
UBS VIEW Value for long-term investors, but we think further volatility looks likely. We see value in the
sector overall, especially for investors taking a longer-term view. However, given the wide range of
possible outcomes given the pending uncertainties around the UK economic outlook, we would expect
volatility to remain a feature for share prices.
EVIDENCE Pricing, reservations rates and FCF generation the key indicators. It is still very early post the EU
Referendum so the actual impact on trading remains to be seen. We will therefore watch in particular
changes in reservation rates and prices over the coming months to gain more insight into how realistic
our new base case scenario is. Critical, in our view, will be company reactions to mitigate potential
earnings declines, which we expect mainly to occur via reduced land buying and cost reduction efforts.

PM

Sorry for the formatting

11:53 am
PM

PM

While the decision to leave the European
Union has created short-term uncertainty
in the prime London property market, this
needs to be viewed in the context of events
in the two-year period preceding the vote.
In June 2014, annual growth in prime central
London reached 8.1% before it began a
steady decline to -1.8% in August 2016.
Two major factors caused the slowdown.
First, the scope for future increases was
limited following a four-year period of
exceptionally strong growth. Second,
two stamp duty hikes and a series of tax
changes accelerated this process.
This period of government intervention has
led to deepening distortions in the London
housing market, which we examine in more
detail on page 3.

PM

The single biggest factor that curbed
demand in the 18 months prior to the
referendum was the increase in stamp duty
in December 2014, widely seen as a political
manoeuvre by the former Chancellor George
Osborne ahead of a general election.
This measure has loomed larger than any
other over the market, compounded by the
introduction in April this year of the additional
rate of stamp duty equating to three percent
for buy-to-let properties and second home
buyers.

11:53 am
PM

The result of this two-year slowdown is that
vendors were already adapting to the new
pricing environment and in many cases Brexit
became a trigger to make overdue reductions
to asking prices.
In the two months since the vote, while many
buyers have sought asking price reductions
the majority of sellers are adopting a waitand-see
approach though low to mid-singledigit
declines are common.
There is no uniform picture however, and
where asking prices were set at realistic
levels before the EU vote, transactions have
been achieved at or around the asking price.
Furthermore, currency is playing a more
significant role, with the weaker pound
spurring interest from buyers denominated
in foreign currencies. The volatility of sterling
in the past few weeks is leading many
to speculate that overseas interest in the
London market will filter through more
strongly when there is greater confidence that
the pound has hit its low point.
It should also be remembered that other
asset classes are showing weak returns.
Bond yields are at historic lows, hedge funds
are struggling to anticipate central bank
policy and many believe stocks look fully
priced after successive rounds of quantitative
easing.

PM

Hackney, Southwark and
Lewisham recorded the largest
rises in the number of property
sales between £1 million and £2
million

BE

Meanwhile, UBS suggesting you might want to cut a bit on the sector's recent rally.

11:56 am
BE

Following evidence suggesting UK residential market trends have been more resilient
than expected than immediately after the EU Referendum, we move to a scenario of
0% volume growth and 0% net inflation, from previously -15% and -5%, respectively
for 2017/18E. While current run rates suggest better dynamics than this, we apply
some prudence given risks of a lagged impact on the sector. Shares have recovered
c40% since the bottom but remain c18% below the 23rd June level. Our new scenario
leaves upside of 25% (TSR) on average, but we downgrade Barratt and Bovis to Neutral
(from Buy) and reiterate our Buy ratings on the Bellway, Berkeley, Crest Nicholson,
Persimmon, Redrow and Taylor Wimpey and our Sell rating on McCarthy & Stone.

PM

(Boncoeur -- fair enough -- Lewisham borough...)

BE

Market dynamics have been significantly more benign in July/August following the EU
Referendum: after an initial dip, reservation rates have generally recovered and were on
average up c3% y/y in July/August, against a tough basis of comparison. Other market
indicators such as the RICS have also shown a stabilisation in price expectations
following an initial dip with most indicators suggesting prices are showing no signs of
deflation. In general, secondary market trends have been somewhat softer with lower
transactions, as have high-end London dynamics, though both of these may be more
attributable to the changes in stamp duty in April rather than the Referendum. For the
new build sector, Help-to-Buy has been a key driver of support. Housing policy from the
new Government will be important and we expect the shared equity element of Helpto-Buy
to be maintained given the success of stimulating new build construction.

11:57 am
BE

The initial exercise following the EU Referendum was to calibrate the potential
downside risk which we concluded was relatively low compared to upside. After the
rebound, we believe the market is pricing in some modest house price deflation.
Considering (1) attractive yields of 6.6% and 7.7x P/E CY17E; (2) supportive
government policy; (3) strong balance sheets which are mostly net cash, we remain
positive on the sector although become more balanced in our recommendation profile.
Our top picks remain Berkeley, Bellway and Persimmon.

What is being offered is a very rare opportunity to purchase this former warehouse which offers exceptional lateral space currently presented as a shell; four walls and an unloved roof - in short, a wreck!
